citeinfo.title: Russian Empire Playing Cards: Geography of the Provinces (shapefile)

descript.abstract: Geographic boundaries corresponding to the 77 Russian Empire province playing cards, 1856. Part of the Russian Empire geographic playing cards data, 1856. Geospatial data sets derived from a set of geographic data playing cards of the Russian Empire produced by Konstantin Matveevich Gribanov and published in 1856. The cards were digitized as part of the Meeting of Frontiers project by the Library of Congress and Russian National Library. The geospatial data files were produced as part of The Imperiia Project: A Spatial History of the Russian Empire by Kelly O'Neill, Harvard University. This data collection provides source card data in multiple digital formats (shapefile, GeoJSON, csv, and xslx) georeferenced to administrative boundaries sourced from the Geographical Atlas of the Russian Empire (GARE) including province and regional boundaries, rivers, and towns. For more information view the readme files provided with the collection data or visit The Imperiia Project project page: https://imperiia.scalar.fas.harvard.edu/imperiia/the-playing-cards
descript.purpose: This dataset for use in GIS software.

cntaddr.address: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies

cntinfo.hours: Regular business hours are 9 a.m.–5 p.m. Monday through Friday

horizpa.horizpar: Administrative boundaries were sourced from the Geographical Atlas of the Russian Empire (GARE) published in the 1820s and adapted to reflect boundary changes made in the decades leading up to 1857. Town locations were also sourced from GARE. The points (towns) and polygons (provinces) are extraordinarily accurate representations of the data depicted on the atlas. GARE is recognized as the most comprehensive and accurate mapping of the empire prior to the middle of the 19th century. That said, the maps that compose the atlas were produced at different scales and in different projections. Together with the fact that the resolution of contemporary geospatial data is uniformly higher, this means that the despite the fact that this is the highest-quality data of its kind, users will find that the historical spatial data defines space slightly differently. Inaccuracy is not uniform across the data: it is more pronounced along the coastlines. (Additional note: The geojson and csv files for "towns" also include modern coordinate locations

citeinfo.title: Geographic Card Set of the Russian Empire
Geograficheskīĭ atlas Rossīĭskoĭ Imperīi
citeinfo.othercit: 1 atlas (83 leaves in various foliations) : 60 hand colored maps ; 44 x 53 cm

procstep.procdesc: This data is sourced from a set of geographic playing cards produced in the 1850s. There is one playing card for each province of the Russian Empire. They were meant to be a pedagogical tool at the time, but contain lots of useful statistical information. The cards are held and digitized by the Library of Congress. The information from the cards has been extracted and spatialized as part of the Imperiia Project. To learn more about the original playing cards, you can visit the digital exhibition: https://scalar.fas.harvard.edu/imperiia/card-sorts?path=the-playing-cards

enttyp.enttypd: Playing Cards: Geography of the provinces

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
unique identifier for each card based on the numerals assigned to the original playing cards.

attr.attrdef: province or region name, in English

attrdomv.udom: simplified English names; standard English spellings used where available (such as "Lifland" instead of "Lifliand"); the word "province" (translation of guberniia and oblast') is omitted.

attr.attrdef: area of province in square versts. 1 square verst = 0.44 square miles
area of province in square miles
text note on climate - Climate is described with one or more adjectives.

climate index - A rough (and somewhat fun) index of how favorable the weather would seem to be in each province based on the positive/negative qualities of the adjectives used in the text note. It is a sum of the values assigned to each listed term. For values see "GeoCards_ref_index_climate." (https://demo.dataverse.org/file.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.70122/FK2/NYWWNE/KLLQ4D&version=1.0)
